notes.plain: The string data type can contain characters, line feeds, carriage returns, and tab characters.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: The string data type can contain characters, line feeds, carriage returns, and tab characters.

notes.plain:
Items which are represent a boolean data option, such as true/false or yes/no answers. Use for such data, it is important to devise the meanings (usually questions in subjective data) carefully, so that the only allowed results are in fact true or false. Potential MisUse: The DvBoolean class should not be used as a replacement for naively modelled enumerated types such as male/female etc. Such values should be coded, and in any case the enumeration often has more than two values.
Though the DvBoolean.dv attribute is a String type this is to easily allow responses that the user is more familiar with using in the context such as 'Yes', 'No' or 'True', 'False'. A conversion method is required to convert the valid_trues to True and the valid_falses to False.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Items which are represent a
boolean data option
, such as true/false or yes/no answers.
Use for such data, it is important to devise the meanings (usually questions in subjective data) carefully, so that the only allowed results are in fact true or false.
Potential MisUse:

The DvBoolean class should not be used as a replacement for naively modelled enumerated types such as male/female etc. Such values should be coded, and in any case the enumeration often has more than two values.

Though the DvBoolean.dv attribute is a String type this is to easily allow responses that the user is more familiar with using in the context such as 'Yes', 'No' or 'True', 'False'. A conversion method is required to convert the valid_trues to True and the valid_falses to False.
Valid Time Begin. If present this must be a valid datetime including timezone. It is used to indicate the beginning time that information is considered valid.

notes.plain: Valid Time Begin. If present this must be a valid datetime including timezone. It is used to indicate the beginning time that information is considered valid.

html.xhtml:p: Valid Time End. If present this must be a valid date-time including timezone. It is used to indicate the ending time that information is considered valid or the time the information expired or will expire.

notes.plain: Valid Time End. If present this must be a valid date-time including timezone. It is used to indicate the ending time that information is considered valid or the time the information expired or will expire.

html.xhtml:p: Time Recorded. If present this must be a valid date-time stamp. It is used to indicate the the actual date and time the data was recorded.

notes.plain: Time Recorded. If present this must be a valid date-time stamp. It is used to indicate the the actual date and time the data was recorded.

html.xhtml:p: Time Modified. If present this must be a valid date-time stamp. It is used to indicate the the actual date and time the data was last changed.

notes.plain: Time Modified. If present this must be a valid date-time stamp. It is used to indicate the the actual date and time the data was last changed.

html.xhtml:p: Latitude in decimal format. Value range -90.000000 to 90.000000.

notes.plain: Latitude in decimal format. Value range -90.000000 to 90.000000.

html.xhtml:p: Longitude in decimal format. Value range -180.000000 to 180.000000.

notes.plain: Longitude in decimal format. Value range -180.000000 to 180.000000.
Descriptive name of this datatype model. Provides the semantic 'name' for the model. Replaces what would be XML element name, column name or class name in other modeling paradigms.

html.xhtml:p: Descriptive name of this datatype model. Provides the semantic 'name' for the model. Replaces what would be XML element name, column name or class name in other modeling paradigms.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Serves as the common ancestor of all eXtended data-types (Xd*) in S3Model.

notes.plain: Serves as the common ancestor of all eXtended data-types (Xd*) in S3Model.
Used to specify a URI. Set the pattern to accommodate your needs.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Used to specify a URI.
Set the pattern to accommodate your needs.

notes.plain: Encapsulated data expressed as a parsable String. The internal model of the data item is not described in the MLHIM model in common with other encapsulated types, but in this case, the form of the data is assumed to be plaintext, rather than compressed or other types of large binary data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Encapsulated data expressed as a parsable String. The internal model of the
data item is not described in the MLHIM model in common with other encapsulated types, but in this case, the form of the data is assumed to be plaintext, rather
than compressed or other types of large binary data.

notes.plain:
Abstract class defining the concept of ordered values, which includes ordinals as well as true quantities.
The implementations require the functions ‘<’, '>' and is_strictly_comparable_to ('==').

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Abstract class defining the concept of ordered values, which includes ordinals as
well as true quantities.
The implementations
require the functions ‘<’, '>' and is_strictly_comparable_to ('==').

notes.plain: Models rankings and scores, e.g. pain, Apgar values, etc, where there is a) implied ordering, b) no implication that the distance between each value is con- stant, and c) the total number of values is finite. Note that although the term ‘ordinal’ in mathematics means natural numbers only, here any integer is allowed, since negative and zero values are often used by medical professionals for values around a neutral point. Examples of sets of ordinal values: -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3 -- reflex response values 0, 1, 2 -- Apgar values Used for recording any clinical datum which is customarily recorded using sym- bolic values. Example: the results on a urinalysis strip, e.g. {neg, trace, +, ++, +++} are used for leucocytes, protein, nitrites etc; for non-haemolysed blood {neg, trace, moderate}; for haemolysed blood {neg, trace, small, moderate, large}.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Models rankings and scores, e.g. pain, Apgar values, etc, where there is a)
implied ordering, b) no implication that the distance between each value is con-
stant, and c) the total number of values is finite. Note that although the term
‘ordinal’ in mathematics means natural numbers only, here any integer is
allowed, since negative and zero values are often used by medical professionals
for values around a neutral point. Examples of sets of ordinal values:
-3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3 -- reflex response values
0, 1, 2 -- Apgar values
Used for recording any clinical datum which is customarily recorded using sym-
bolic values. Example: the results on a urinalysis strip, e.g. {neg, trace, +,
++, +++} are used for leucocytes, protein, nitrites etc; for non-haemolysed
blood {neg, trace, moderate}; for haemolysed blood {neg, trace,
small, moderate, large}.

notes.plain:
Class defining the concept of date and time types. Must be constrained in CCDs to be one or more of the "dvtemporal-..." elements. This gives the modeller the ability to optionally allow partial dates at run time. Setting maxOccurs and minOccurs to zero cause the element to be prohibitied.
For example to allow a full date or only a month and year: Set all maxOccurs = 0 except dvtemporal-date and dvtemporal-month-year, leaves those as maxOccurs=1

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Class defining the concept of date and time types.
Must be constrained in CCDs to be one or more of the "dvtemporal-..." elements.
This gives the modeller the ability to optionally allow partial dates at run time. Setting maxOccurs and minOccurs to zero cause the element to be prohibitied.
For example to allow a full date or only a month and year:
Set all maxOccurs = 0 except dvtemporal-date and
dvtemporal-month-year, leaves those as maxOccurs=1

notes.plain: Abstract class defining the concept of true quantified values, i.e. values which are not only ordered, but which have a precise magnitude.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Abstract class defining the concept of true quantified values, i.e. values which are
not only ordered, but which have a precise magnitude.

notes.plain:
Countable quantities.
Used for countable types such as pregnancies and steps (taken by a physiotherapy patient), number of cigarettes smoked in a day, etc.
Misuse:Not used for amounts of physical entities (which all have standardized units)

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Countable quantities.
Used for countable types such as pregnancies and steps (taken by a physiotherapy patient), number of cigarettes smoked in a day, etc.
Misuse:
Not used for amounts of physical entities (which all have standardized
units)

notes.plain:
Quantitified type representing “scientific” quantities, i.e. quantities expressed as a magnitude and units. Units were inspired by the Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM), developed by Gunther Schadow and Clement J. McDonald of The Regenstrief Institute. http://unitsofmeasure.org/
Can also be used for time durations, where it is more convenient to treat these as simply a number of individual seconds, minutes, hours, days, months, years, etc.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Quantitified type representing “scientific” quantities, i.e. quantities expressed as a magnitude and units.
Units were inspired by the Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM), developed by Gunther Schadow and Clement J. McDonald of The Regenstrief Institute.
http://unitsofmeasure.org/
Can also be used for time durations, where it is more convenient to treat these as
simply a number of individual seconds, minutes, hours, days, months, years, etc.

notes.plain: Models a ratio of values, i.e. where the numerator and denominator are both pure numbers. Used for recording generic ratios that can not be cathegorized as rates or proportions, such as titers (e.g. 1:128), concentration ratios, e.g. Na:K (unitary denominator), albumin:creatinine ratio, even when presented as percentages, e.g. red cell distribution width (RDW). Should not be used to represent things like blood pressure which are often written using a ‘/’ character, giving the misleading impression that the item is a ratio, when in fact it is a structured value. Similarly, visual acuity, often written as (e.g.) “6/24” in clinical notes is not a ratio but an ordinal (which includes non-numeric symbols like CF = count fingers etc). Should not be used for formulations. Rates and Proportions should use the DvRatio children classes, respectively DvRate and DvProportion.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Models a ratio of values, i.e. where the numerator and denominator are both pure numbers. Used for recording generic ratios that can not be cathegorized as rates or proportions, such as titers (e.g. 1:128), concentration ratios, e.g. Na:K (unitary denominator), albumin:creatinine ratio, even when presented as percentages, e.g. red cell distribution width (RDW). Should not be used to represent things like blood pressure which are often written using a ‘/’ character, giving the misleading impression that the item is a ratio, when in fact it is a structured value. Similarly, visual acuity, often written as (e.g.) “6/24” in clinical notes is not a ratio but an ordinal (which includes non-numeric symbols like CF = count fingers etc).
Should not be used for formulations.
Rates and Proportions should use the DvRatio children classes, respectively DvRate and DvProportion.

notes.plain:
Generic class defining an interval (i.e. range) of a comparable type. An interval is a contiguous subrange of a comparable base type.
Used to define intervals of dates, times, quantities Whose units match and datatypes are the same and are ordered.
If the implementation technology has a concept of intervals AND the technology provides for multiple inheritance, then this class may inherit directly from it.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Generic class defining an interval (i.e. range) of a comparable type. An interval is
a contiguous subrange of a comparable base type.
Used to define intervals of dates, times, quantities Whose units match and datatypes are the same and are
ordered
If the implementation technology has a concept of intervals AND the technology provides for multiple inheritance, then this class may inherit directly from it.

notes.plain:
Defines a named range to be associated with any ORDERED datum. Each such range is particular to the patient and context, e.g. sex, age, and any other factor which affects ranges.
May be used to represent normal, therapeutic, dangerous, critical etc ranges.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Defines a named range to be associated with any ORDERED datum. Each such
range is particular to the patient and context, e.g. sex, age, and any other factor
which affects ranges.
May be used to represent normal, therapeutic, dangerous, critical etc ranges.
